CARDINAL . Mr PERSON was charged under section CARDINAL of LAW ( Mediengesetz – see paragraph CARDINAL below ) for having exercised prohibited influence on criminal proceedings ( verbotene PERSON ) .

CARDINAL . The court recalled that in DATE Mr PERSON had been convicted of tax evasion ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . In establishing whether the impugned article was capable of influencing the result of these proceedings , the court noted that the wording and content of the article as a whole , as well as the development of the proceedings reported upon , the person of the accused , and the person of the applicant had to be taken into account . The article , unlike court reports of the scandal press , analysed the conduct of the presiding judge , the public prosecutor , defence counsel and in particular the accused , Mr PERSON , almost as a psychologist would have done .

Furthermore , the court found that it was clear for every reader , who was vaguely familiar with the issue , that the applicant , who had been working for ORG for DATE , had intensively dealt with the so - called “ Causa Androsch ” and had frequently reported on it . It appeared from the article that the applicant assumed that the investigations carried out by the tax authorities were correct . He subjected the statements made by the accused at the trial to a critical psychological analysis . However , his way of writing and the wording used were not capable of influencing these proceedings . Even to a lay judge , the applicant 's person and his activities as a journalist in the PERSON case were well known . Thus he would not expect the applicant to give a neutral account of the proceedings .

Moreover , it had not been established that the applicant had acted with the intention of influencing the outcome of the proceedings , in particular as it appeared that he was convinced that Mr Androsch would in any event be convicted .

“ The prosecution appeal is therefore well - founded . It rightly takes as its starting - point that the offence defined in section CARDINAL of LAW must be classified as a potentially endangering offence [ abstraktes ORG ] …
